name: market for sweet corn | sweet corn | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/30145/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for 'sweet corn', in the geography of Minnesota state in the United States of America.;Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.;The product 'sweet corn' is a vegetable. It is an annual crop.

The activity starts at the gate of sweet corn cultivation farm.

This activity ends with the supply of 'sweet corn', to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are considered.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is the same as stated in the transforming activity for the same reference product.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data represent the situation in Minnesota state in the United States of America.

flow.name: sweet corn
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

exchanges.description:
Sweet corn is transported on average 96 km by lorry (100%) in the US. Data from 2006. It is assumed that the sweet corn is transported with refrigeration, since sweet corn is a highly perishable crop. When produced for commercial markets, it must be cooled immediately and thoroughly after harvest to protect its quality. It must be kept cool until it reaches the consumer.
The share between the types of lorry was extrapolated from other GLO markets of crops. Original comment: "It is estimated (based on production volumes), that 90% of the transport by lorry is by big lorries which carry a reefer and 10% by small lorries with build in refrigeration machine".
References:
Jean Miller Melissa. Cradle to Consumer Life Cycle Greenhouse Gas Accounting of Sweet Corn in Minnesota. FACULTY OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA. 2017
https://conservancy.umn.edu/bitstream/handle/11299/191252/Miller_umn_0130M_18041.pdf?sequence=1
https://content.ces.ncsu.edu/postharvest-cooling-and-handling-of-sweet-corn 
https://usatruckloadshipping.com/how-to-ship-georgia-sweet-corn/
https://usatruckloadshipping.com/how-is-corn-packaged-and-shipped/
https://www.vegetables.bayer.com/nz/en-nz/resources/growing-tips/agronomic-spotlights/postharvest-sweet-corn-handling-and-storage.html#:~:text=To%20continue%20to%20help%20maintain,moisture%20loss%20and%20maintain%20temperature.&text=The%20recommended%20temperature%20during%20transit,between%2095%25%20to%2098%25.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value extrapolated from other GLO markets for crops.
Original comment: The reefer operates (is cooling or freezing down the goods) no matter if it is being transported or if it is standing in a port or farm and not moving. The amount of operation of reefer needed is connected directly to different modes of transport using default assumptions on the average speed of the infrastructure.
This exchange represents the time, when the reefer is being transferred from one mode of the transport to another. So for example the reefer is taken by a truck to the port, where it is transferred to a transoceanic ship. During this time the transport vehicles are not moving, but the reefer keeps operating and maintaining the required atmosphere.
Based on an estimate 20% of amount of operation, reefer, cooling is added to cover the time when the reefer is transferred between different types of transport.  So, for example, if the goods stay and is being transported by the different modes of transport for 10 days there are 2 more days added that represent the time when the reefer is being transferred from the truck to the ship and from the ship to the train, etc.

flow.name: operation, reefer, cooling

exchanges.description:
Extrapolated from other GLO markets of crops. 
Original comment: Calculated value. The amount of fruit which is spoiled and thrown out during the transport between the producers and the consumers is represented by two exchanges; the additional 0.12 kg of the fruit and the same amount of biowaste created.
